titleStmt.title: A New Poem on the Bishops

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Old Latimer Preaching did fairly describe
A Bishop who rul'd all the rest of the Tribe
But who is this Bishop & where does he dwell
why truly twas Satan ArchBishop of Hell
And, He was a Primate & he wore A Mitre
Surrounded with Iewels of Sulpher and Nitre
How nearly His Bishop our Bishops resembles
but this had the Odds who belives & who trembles
Cou'd yo see his Grim Grace for a Pound to a penny
You'd Swear it must be the Baboon of Kilkenny
Poor Satan will think the Comparison odious
I wish I cou'd find him out one more comodious
But this I am sure the most Rev'd Old Dragon
Has got on the Bench many Bishops Suffragan
And all men beleives he presides there in Cogg
to give them by turns an invisible Iogg
Our Prelates puft up with Wealth & with Pride
To Hell on the Backs of the Clergy would ride
they mounted & Labour'd with whip & with Spurr
In vain for the Devill a Parson would Stirr
So the Comons unhorst them & this was their Doom
On their Crosiers to ride like A Witch on a Broom
Tho they Gallop So fast on the road you may find them
And left us but Three out of twenty behind them
Lord Boltons good Grace Lord Carr & Lord Howard
In spight of the Devill would Still be untoward
They came of good Blood & Cou'd not endure
their former Companions to beg at their door
When Christ was betrayd to Pilot the Pretor
In a Dozn Appostles but one proved a traytor
One traytor alone & faithfull Eleven
But wee can afford you six overone traytor in Seven
What a Clutter with Clippings dividings & Cleavings
And the Clergy for·sooth Must take up their leavings
If makeing divisions was all their intent
Wee have done it wee thank them but not as they meant
And So may Such Bishops for ever divide
That no Honest Heathen wou'd be on their Side
How should wee rejoyce if like Iudas the first
these Splitters of Parsons in Sunder wou'd burst
Now hear an A overIllusion a Mitre you know
is divided above but united below
If this you consider our Emblem is right
the Bishops but the Clergy unite
Shou'd the Bottom be Splitt our Prelates may dread
that the Mitre will never Stick fast on their Head
And Yet they have learnt the Chief art of a Soverign
As Machivell taught divide & you govern
But Courage my Lords though it cannot be said
that one Cloven tounge ever sate on your Head
I'le hold yo a Groat & I wish I cou'd See't
If your Stockings were of yo cou'd Shew Cloven feet
But hold Cry the Bishopes & give us fair play
before yo condemn us hear wṭ wee can say
What truer affection could ever be Shewn
than saveing Your Souls by damning our own
And have wee not practiced all methods to gain yo
With the Tythe of the Tythe of the Tythe to Maintain You
Provided a fund for building Your Spittals
You are only to live four Years with out Victuals
Content my Good Lords but let us change hands
First take you our Tythes and give us yṛ Lands
So God bless our Church & three of our Mitres
And God bless the Comons for biteing the biters803-023D
